key_insight: RadarGen uses a latent image-diffusion approach to synthesize realistic automotive radar point clouds from multi-view camera images by generating bird's-eye-view (BEV) radar maps that encode spatial layout, RCS and Doppler, then converting them back to points.
problem_solved: Collecting and annotating large-scale real radar point-cloud datasets is expensive and limited; RadarGen enables scalable, visually-aligned radar data synthesis from cameras to augment training, validation and simulation for perception systems.
method: Represent radar measurements as BEV maps that jointly encode geometry, radar cross section (RCS) and Doppler attributes.
Adapt efficient image-latent diffusion to generate these BEV radar maps conditioned on multi-view camera imagery (cross-modal conditioning and scene alignment).
Apply a lightweight recovery module to convert generated BEV maps into realistic radar point clouds suitable for downstream tasks.
impact: Provides a practical way to synthesize realistic radar data for training and testing perception models, improving dataset scale and diversity while lowering reliance on expensive radar collection. Useful for sensor fusion, data augmentation, and simulation-driven development.
visual_elements: Pipeline diagram: multi-view cameras -> conditioned diffusion model -> BEV radar maps -> point-cloud recovery

paper_title: RadarGen: Automotive Radar Point Cloud Generation from Cameras
paper_authors: Tomer Borreda, Fangqiang Ding, Sanja Fidler, Shengyu Huang, Or Litany
